Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Cricothyrotomy Techniques

Participants.evidence: emergency physicians (EPs) and trainees trained in both techniques

Intervention.evidence: a surgical technique using a bougie/endotracheal tube (ETT) and an open technique using the Melker catheter

Objective.evidence: This study compared the time to lung insufflation between a surgical technique using a bougie/endotracheal tube (ETT) and an open technique using the Melker catheter.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the time to first insufflation of the artificial lung.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: randomised via block randomisation with random block sizes

Blinding.evidence: Participants were not blinded to the technique.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Thirty-six participants (17 EPs, 19 trainees) were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: Thirty-six participants (17 EPs, 19 trainees) were randomised to perform both techniques.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The Melker catheter technique was quicker, with a mean time of 29.2 seconds compared to 44.3 seconds for the bougie/ETT technique (difference 15.1 seconds, 95% CI 10.8–19.4 seconds).

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
